bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 31, 1875

div1.p: Emilie Lawrence visits Norfolk and Reed teases her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, October 31, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Octr 31st75.

div1.p:
Is it
possible that the dearest,
darlingest, sweetest, smar-
test woman, in the world has hied
herself to the beautiful City
of Norfolk? I am informed
that such is the case, by
your postal received on
Saturday, & your letter
to-day- Tell Miss Annie
that I will never forgive
her for not allowing you
to finish your letter, ex-
cept on one condition, (and that
is a very easy one to comply
with,) viz: that she acknowledge that there has not
been such a sensible & sweet
woman in Norfolk during the
past year. If she will agree
to this, I'll relent & say no
more about it. Tell her, for
me, that she now has the
only angel, in this world, un-
der her roof, & that I beg
of her to watch over this
angelic being very tenderly
for should aught occur to
frighten or harm her, I should,
at once, cease to exist!
How could you, my little dar-
ling, make up your mind
to leave dear little Murfrees-
boro, with all of its fasci-
nating quietness & fly to
a boisterous & turbelent City
like Norfolk? Ah! I forgot
you said 'twas to visit your
sister- Well, having had the
pleasure of making the ac-
quaintance of that sister, I
do not wonder at your de-
sire to clasp her to your
heart. To your, Emilie darling,
I can say that she is a
sweet lady, & if she appears
thus to me, what must she
be to you, who calls her
sister- That I may be able
to thus address her, one of these
days, is my earnest desire.
However, I am afraid that
one or two events which
occurred, while I was at
home, did not tend to elevate
me in Miss Annie's estima-
tion: such as the little “breeze”
between Mrs. Douglas & myself-
But as I did the “honorable” by
apologizing, I shall try to forget
the matter, & trust that Miss A.
will not judge me too severely.
I know how apt a person is
to form an opinion of another's
disposition by just these triv-
ial happenings, & when once
formed, it is a difficult matter
to dislodge it from one's mind-
But, as I have often told you,
my little E., I have much temper
& many shortcomings, & hence
you will not be disappointed.
Still, I should regret very
much to descend, in the estim-
ation of so charming a lady
as your sister- (All of this by
the way however-)
Being in so large and gay
a City as Norfolk, of course,
there will be no lack of
exciting events to put in
your letters; and hence I
shall expect the most start-
ling incidents. I am very
glad that you have gone
to Norfolk, since I know you
will experience much pleas-
ure from your visit; but
after all of this, I am sad &
solicitous. I'm so afraid that
some of those fascinating lit-
tle beaux of N. will steal
your heart, leaving me so
desolate & forlorn- What
if you should meet with
one, from whose lips flow
words of wisdom - whose
eyes vies with the Gazelle's
in brilliancy & loveliness, and
whose form commanding form
surpasses the rising sun,
(see description of Prof. M., by Miss E.B.L.).
would you not forget the
awkward youth, who ever
walks too fast, who can't
make a fire, or drive a horse,
or gather flowers by the way-
side & who quarrels at the
slightest provocation, & own
your heart enchanted by this
City gentleman? Please, my dar-
ling E. turn a deaf ear to them,
when they prostrate themselves
at your feet. Don't believe a
word they say, for, I assure
you, they are telling stories.

How long will you
remain in N.? How nice it
would have been for me
if I had only postponed
my visit till the present.
I could have thus saved one
day, which was otherwise spent
in travelling. If you will only
promise to remain till next
February, I will make a second
attempt to come, & then we can
ride around (provided you
would not object) & see all the
sights together.

I was down, last week, to see
Dr Cuyler; but since, I believe, I
told you of this, in my last let-
ter, I'll not refer to it in this
one. By the way, has my brother
James called on you, since
your arrival? I must write
to him & tell him to pay you
a call, in order that he may
see what the Old North
State can boast of. Now
don't get frightened, for I am
not going to tell him for some
time yet-not till he comes to New
York, which will be about
the 12th of this Novr. You need not
be disappointed at not receiv-
ing very long letters, while he
is with me, because I will be
so busy showing him the sights
& talking over old times, that my
opportunities of writing will be
limited. For this miserably discon-
nected letter, I must ask your in-
dulgence- I could do better, as there
were 5 officers sitting in the same
room with me & conversing on
as many topics- Remember me
very kindly to your sisters-

closer.salute:
Believe me, as ever,
Your fond & devoted
